title: Cache Active Indices Efficiently
body: Opening this issue to discussion memory efficient strategy to allow more cached values for active validator indices. One easy optimization for now is to store the list of inactive validators. Data structure is easy with a map, if an index is not present in the map then it is active. Another suggestion is a radix tree

From talking with @prestonvanloon:
- radix trie can reduce storage, may have more insertion cost, and some retrieval cost
- inverse validator set can save on space for the for seeable future, but it is not a long term strategy (it may only buy a few years of efficency)
radix  trie should be easy since we are just using 64 bit numbers
I can start working on radix trie

1.B-Tree - self balanced binary tree , has 5 properties. Used in postgres by default.
Worst Case
Search  O(log n)
Insert  O(log n)
Delete  O(log n)

B-tree is used to stotre database indices in Postgres
https://ieftimov.com/post/postgresql-indexes-btree/
Limitations: expensive Insert operation in larger trees.

2.B+Tree offers some performance gain due to linked leaves structure and absense of interior nodes.
Speed - Worst Case
Search O(log n)
Insert O(log n)
Delete O(log n)

Variables:
Index s
Index length(number of digits) m
Total length of all indexes : M
The number of all indexes stored in a trie n
Size of committee N  ( i am not sure here as it is size of alphabet in case we deal with strings)

1.Trie

Trie Add O(mN)
Trie remove O(mN)
Trie Search O(m)
If M is total length of all indexes stored in a trie then the storage used is O(MN)

2.Patricia trie - all internal nodes in Patricia trie have at least two children where all internal nodes in a trie have at least 1 child. We maximize storage efficiency by grouping indexes that have one child in patricia trie.

Patricia Trie Add O(mN)
Patricia Trie Remove O(mN)
Patricia Trie Search O(m)
If M is total length of all indexes stored in a Patricia trie then the storage used is O(nN + M)

Conclusion. We save some in storage with Patricia trie

from talk with @prestonvanloon : i think there are still better data structures out there
at least for the active validator indices set
this is a very dense sequence of integers
i'm thinking of a range trie/tree or similar

Range tree is perfect balanced binary search tree that enables many operations including range_query
TREE-Search O(h) where h is height if the tree
Each nide contains attributes, key, left and right and pointer that points to node's left child
Operations and time complexity:
Tree-Minimum (The most left element)  O(h)
Tree-Maximum  ( themsot right element) O(h)
Tree Successor O(h)
Tree Predecessor O(h)
Tree-Insert 0(h)
TREE-Delete O(h) 


Red black Trees
A red-black tree is a binary search tree with one extra bit of storage per node: its
color, which can be either RED or BLACK. That property enables to keep a tree approximately balanced.
Red black Trees Contain fllowing attributes: color, key, left, right, and p
Operations: Search, Minimum, Maximum, Successor, Predesessor O(lg n) time
Insertion O(lg(n))
Deletion O(lg(n))
I assume, we have to run only Insert, Search, Delete operations over validator indices so Red Black tree is less expensive.

To clarify the requirements for this issue:
- Write benchmarks to explain the CPU and memory costs of the current implementation
- Explore a few ideas with the same benchmark and compare the results
- If there exists some non-trivial improvement, then we'll accept a PR with the better data structure.

Map may be okay for this task but  it is not designed for efficient membership check. Trees are also good but may not be memory efficient and could be  demanding.

I am thinking that Bloom filters are what you need here. They are for membership related tasks. 
A Bloom filter is a data structure designed to tell you, rapidly and memory-efficiently, whether an element is present in a set. However it is a probabilistic data structure. A Bloom filter with m bits and k hashing functions, both insertion and membership testing are O(k). This is a great win and it decouple the set size from computation speed.
https://llimllib.github.io/bloomfilter-tutorial/
@janus what about [this](https://github.com/bradfitz/gomemcache)?
if this bounty is still open i'd like to consider working on it this week since i've finally managed to get a new laptop to replace the macbook i lost.
